title: CGNTIEZ provides $20 million supplier credit for 74MW Kyi-Ohn Kyi-Wa Hydroelectric Power Plant Construction Project
description: On July 7, 2004, the China Guangdong New Technology Import and Export Zhuhai Company (CGNTIEZ) signed a $20 million supplier credit agreement with the Government of Myanmar’s Department of Irrigation (Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation) for the 74MW Kyi-Ohn Kyi-Wa Hydroelectric Power Plant Construction Project. The supplier credit carried a maturity of 7 years. However, its interest rate and grace period are unknown. The proceeds from the supplier credit were to be used by the borrower to facilitate the acquisition and installation of equipment — including supply turbine generators, watergate doors, steel pipes, water sluice doors, a switchyard and a powerhouse — from CGNTIEZ for the construction of the Kyi-Ohn Kyi-Wa hydroelectric power plant on the Mone Chaung River within Sidoktaya township, Minbu district, and Magway state (exact locational coordinates:  20.331000, 94.416000).   The project scope included a 50 meter high earth dam that would create a reservoir inundating 33 km2 and storing of 571 hm3. The 74 MW power plant would be located at the toe of the dam. Two diversion weirs would divert water for irrigation downstream of the Kyeeon Kyeewa power plant before the Mone Chaung reaches the Ayeyarwady. The power plant would be connected to Mann substation by a 70 km long 132 kV transmission line. CGNTIEZ was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project was ultimately completed on March 31, 2012.   This project is also known as the 74MW Kyeeon Kyeewa Hydroelectric Power Plant Construction Project. The Chinese project title is 吉荣吉瓦水电站.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
CGNTIEZ provides $20 million supplier credit for 74MW Kyi-Ohn Kyi-Wa Hydroelectric Power Plant Construction Project

# Description
On July 7, 2004, the China Guangdong New Technology Import and Export Zhuhai Company (CGNTIEZ) signed a $20 million supplier credit agreement with the Government of Myanmar’s Department of Irrigation (Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation) for the 74MW Kyi-Ohn Kyi-Wa Hydroelectric Power Plant Construction Project. The supplier credit carried a maturity of 7 years. However, its interest rate and grace period are unknown. The proceeds from the supplier credit were to be used by the borrower to facilitate the acquisition and installation of equipment — including supply turbine generators, watergate doors, steel pipes, water sluice doors, a switchyard and a powerhouse — from CGNTIEZ for the construction of the Kyi-Ohn Kyi-Wa hydroelectric power plant on the Mone Chaung River within Sidoktaya township, Minbu district, and Magway state (exact locational coordinates:  20.331000, 94.416000).   The project scope included a 50 meter high earth dam that would create a reservoir inundating 33 km2 and storing of 571 hm3. The 74 MW power plant would be located at the toe of the dam. Two diversion weirs would divert water for irrigation downstream of the Kyeeon Kyeewa power plant before the Mone Chaung reaches the Ayeyarwady. The power plant would be connected to Mann substation by a 70 km long 132 kV transmission line. CGNTIEZ was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project was ultimately completed on March 31, 2012.   This project is also known as the 74MW Kyeeon Kyeewa Hydroelectric Power Plant Construction Project. The Chinese project title is 吉荣吉瓦水电站.
justification: Primary purpose is hydroelectric power generation, a renewable energy source
evidence: 74MW hydroelectric power plant, renewable energy focus, includes dam and reservoir for power generation

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 15 million loan for the New Generator Plant Construction Project in Sinde (linked to project #85365)
description: In 2004, the Chinese Government and the Government of Myanmar signed an RMB 80 million loan agreement for various projects (recorded in project #85365). RMB 15 million of the loan proceeds were reportedly used to build a new generator plant in Sinde. Myanmar’s Ministry of Industry, which received the loan, purchased generator parts for this plant from China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation on November 22, 2004.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 15 million loan for the New Generator Plant Construction Project in Sinde (linked to project #85365)

# Description
In 2004, the Chinese Government and the Government of Myanmar signed an RMB 80 million loan agreement for various projects (recorded in project #85365). RMB 15 million of the loan proceeds were reportedly used to build a new generator plant in Sinde. Myanmar’s Ministry of Industry, which received the loan, purchased generator parts for this plant from China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation on November 22, 2004.
justification: Generator plant construction without specification of energy source suggests likely fossil fuel usage
evidence: New generator plant construction, unspecified energy source, purchased generator parts

title: Chinese government grants RMB 28 million for upgrading of Zhangfeng-Bhamo road
description: In 2004, local county governments in the Yunnan province granted 28 million CNY (3.38 million USD) to the upgrade of the Zhangfeng-Bhamo road. The project is referred to as 章凤至缅甸八莫公路 or 章八公路.   Additionally, the Zhangfeng-Moemauk Road Construction Co based in Zhangfeng will provide all upgrades and repairs to the road for 10 years free of charge. Construction began in December 2004 and was completed in 2007. The agreement to construct the highway was signed in Yangon on Nov. 4, between China's Zhangfeng-Momauk Road construction company and Myanmar's Construction Ministry.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Chinese government grants RMB 28 million for upgrading of Zhangfeng-Bhamo road

# Description
In 2004, local county governments in the Yunnan province granted 28 million CNY (3.38 million USD) to the upgrade of the Zhangfeng-Bhamo road. The project is referred to as 章凤至缅甸八莫公路 or 章八公路.   Additionally, the Zhangfeng-Moemauk Road Construction Co based in Zhangfeng will provide all upgrades and repairs to the road for 10 years free of charge. Construction began in December 2004 and was completed in 2007. The agreement to construct the highway was signed in Yangon on Nov. 4, between China's Zhangfeng-Momauk Road construction company and Myanmar's Construction Ministry.
justification: Road upgrade project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Transport infrastructure project focused on road upgrades and maintenance

title: China donates 30 Audi Cars to Myanmar
description: On 24 March 2004, upon Chinese Vice Premier Wu Yi's visit to Myanmar, the Chinese and the Burmese government signed the "Agreement on Economic and Technical Cooperation between China and Myanmar". The Chinese government then presented the Burmese government 30 China-made Audi A6 Sedan cars.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China donates 30 Audi Cars to Myanmar

# Description
On 24 March 2004, upon Chinese Vice Premier Wu Yi's visit to Myanmar, the Chinese and the Burmese government signed the "Agreement on Economic and Technical Cooperation between China and Myanmar". The Chinese government then presented the Burmese government 30 China-made Audi A6 Sedan cars.
justification: Project involves donation of vehicles for government use with no clear environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of 30 Audi A6 Sedan cars for government use, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 12.4 million grant for National Theater Renovation Project (linked to projects #85373 and #64998)
description: On March 24, 2004, the Chinese Government and the Government of Myanmar signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed RMB 50 million of grant funding for multiple projects (recorded in project #85373). The projects supported by this grant commitment were the Rice Milling Machine Installation Project (recorded in project #64998) and the National Theater Renovation Project (recorded in this project), which cost RMB 12.4 million and provided for the renovation of Yangon National Cultural Theatre. This project is completed.
staff_comments: The National Theater in Yangon was originally constructed in the 1980s with financial support from the Chinese Government. It was subsequently renovated in 2016 with a grant from the Chinese Government (captured in Project ID#64498).
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 12.4 million grant for National Theater Renovation Project (linked to projects #85373 and #64998)

# Description
On March 24, 2004, the Chinese Government and the Government of Myanmar signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed RMB 50 million of grant funding for multiple projects (recorded in project #85373). The projects supported by this grant commitment were the Rice Milling Machine Installation Project (recorded in project #64998) and the National Theater Renovation Project (recorded in this project), which cost RMB 12.4 million and provided for the renovation of Yangon National Cultural Theatre. This project is completed.
justification: Project focuses on cultural infrastructure renovation without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: National Theater renovation, cultural infrastructure focus, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 60 million interest-free loan to Myanmar— via March 2004 ETCA — for acquisition and installation of 200 electric water pumps (Linked to Project ID#64759)
description: On March 24, 2004, the Chinese Government and the Government of Myanmar signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed an RMB 200 million interest-free loan for multiple projects (recorded in project #64759). The proceeds of the loan were used by various government ministries in Myanmar. The Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation used RMB 60 million of the loan proceeds to facilitate the acquisition and installation of 200 electric water pumps, which is recorded in this project.
staff_comments: 1. Since the borrowing terms of the interest-free loan are unavailable, AidData has set the maturity to 20 years by default and grace period to 10 years by default p, er China's Foreign Assistance White Paper (http://www.cidca.gov.cn/2018-08/06/c_129925064_3.htm) which states that the maturity of interest-free loans is 20 years, with a drawdown period of 5 years, grace period of 5 years, and repayment over 10 years. AidData treats the drawdown period as providing 5 years of additional grace.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 60 million interest-free loan to Myanmar— via March 2004 ETCA — for acquisition and installation of 200 electric water pumps (Linked to Project ID#64759)

# Description
On March 24, 2004, the Chinese Government and the Government of Myanmar signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed an RMB 200 million interest-free loan for multiple projects (recorded in project #64759). The proceeds of the loan were used by various government ministries in Myanmar. The Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation used RMB 60 million of the loan proceeds to facilitate the acquisition and installation of 200 electric water pumps, which is recorded in this project.
justification: Project focuses on agricultural infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Acquisition and installation of 200 electric water pumps for agricultural use

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 10.33 million interest-free loan — via March 2004 ETCA — to support an oxygen plant and buy spare parts for the iron and steel plants in Pyin Oo Lwin (linked to project #64759)
description: On March 24, 2004, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 200 million interest-free loan (captured in Project ID#64759) — through an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) — to the Government of Myanmar to support various projects and activities overseen by various government ministries. Myanmar’s Ministry of Mines reportedly used RMB 10.33 million of the loan proceeds to support an oxygen plant and buy spare parts for the iron and steel plants in Pyin Oo Lwin district within Mandalay Region.
staff_comments: 1. Since the borrowing terms of the interest-free loan are unavailable, AidData has set the maturity to 20 years by default and grace period to 10 years by default p, er China's Foreign Assistance White Paper (http://www.cidca.gov.cn/2018-08/06/c_129925064_3.htm) which states that the maturity of interest-free loans is 20 years, with a drawdown period of 5 years, grace period of 5 years, and repayment over 10 years. AidData treats the drawdown period as providing 5 years of additional grace.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 10.33 million interest-free loan — via March 2004 ETCA — to support an oxygen plant and buy spare parts for the iron and steel plants in Pyin Oo Lwin (linked to project #64759)

# Description
On March 24, 2004, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 200 million interest-free loan (captured in Project ID#64759) — through an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) — to the Government of Myanmar to support various projects and activities overseen by various government ministries. Myanmar’s Ministry of Mines reportedly used RMB 10.33 million of the loan proceeds to support an oxygen plant and buy spare parts for the iron and steel plants in Pyin Oo Lwin district within Mandalay Region.
